div2.p: Dear John: The soft air of spring is over the land, and it brings a feeling of life & growth, the sweet life of spring. The great silence that bound all out- doors is broken. There are returning birds, & the sap is rising. How good all the things seem after the long winter with its cold & continuing snows.
And no doubt spring is more advance with you, and the greeting of flowers more frequently to be seen. I always thrill to such wondrous beauty rising from the dark earth.

I wrote to you some little time ago asking whether Oct. 19 would be a suitable date for you, & explaining the reason for the suggested change. Actually, I believe that in most years the week beginning Oct 16 (and we would want you to come then) has more beautiful colors than the preceding week. We try to plan our lectures well ahead. Besides I need to get such matters in order before taking off for Hawaii.

Have you by any chance found those copies of your Easter poem? If you could spare a half dozen & autograph them, I should love to have that many. I should then make that many more fans for you. I never give one except to a person who would value it.
Always as I write, a feeling for my dear elder brother upheld in my heart.

I have been doing a little reading in Kazantzaki's The Odyssey, A Modern Sequel. But I found this, a mammoth work exceedingly difficult to understand, the general theme was never clear to me, & the metaphors & other comparisons bewildering And then I get tired of the Yet some of it, I think, is magnificent poetry, or, for example, the four lines on Odysseus death
"As a low lantern's flame flicks in its final blaze
then leaps above its shriveled wick and mounts aloft,
burning with light, and roars toward death with dazzling joy
so did his fierce soul leap before it vanished in air."

I have had two trips this spring. On April 9 & 10 I attended a conference in Charlottesville Va. as a University representative. On the edge of Washington, travelling by bus, I saw the Jefferson Memorial, the stone setting on a water filled ring of cherry blossoms. At Charlottesville, I was lucky in being taken over the grounds of the U. of Virginia. an early institution that is with its white colonial buildings, planned by Jefferson. And to visit it gives one the sense of an earlier time, & of the great men who dominated the founding days of our country. I saw, too, the ten serpentine walls. I had thought that there was only one.

My second and more recent trip was to Chicago where I attended a national conference on school finance, two days of solid meetings. We met in the Loop section, well downtown near the Board of Trade, so I looked upon tall buildings.

School keeps here, but the pace of things quickens examinations, theses, etc. My candidate for the doctorate wrote an excellent theses, & passed an examination with equal I feel very proud of him. And now I am busy with a masters theses written by an Ethiopian. The boy has worked hard, but the language gave him great difficulty. So I am trying to straighten it out. I have had to forget all about style, & to be content with grammar & meaning.

Nita continues with her teaching, and likes it. I am always surprised at the quality of the products that her class turns out. But she has to ride herd on the boys to keep them up to the standard. It is so easy for them to grow careless.

The wave of spring is dashing high over these hills, leaving everywhere a thickening green spray. And how fresh & lovely the newborn colors glow. Once more we look upon creation and it is good. I always feel in spring the lift of eternal things. The grass never forgets, nor do the flowers. The forsythia hangs in long golden strands down the wall back of our house. And now winter departs from our city, the redbud has opened, the fruit trees are abloom, & now & then one can see the white spray of dogwood breaking on the green wall of a wood.
I trust dear, dear friend that all goes well you are often in my thoughts & always in my heart.
